segments.text: Rolf was the one who took her in his car to the recruitment office in Beersheva.
He didn't want her to travel by bus and also wanted to make the most of every minute to be with her.
Most of the girls who arrived there were accompanied by family.
But Yosef had a court hearing about the pink house and she was alone with Rolf.

standing embraced in a corner away from everyone, struggling to part, knowing it wasn't just her enlistment in the army, but also his return to Switzerland and the final days of the pink house, and who knows what tomorrow might bring.
He was very worried about her, but deep down he knew she had the strength to handle whatever came.

Five days had passed and she was already on her way to the weekend leave, wrapped in the uniform that was slightly too big for her, and yet she was very proud of it, wanting her dear father to see her in it.
Only afterward would she be able to take it off.
Maybe shorten and tighten it a bit.
She knew she was standing before the fateful day in her life, the day she would lose the pink house forever.
She had months to prepare for it, but her heart refused to understand, refused to believe, couldn't contain it.
She painted her feelings in pink just like the walls of this beautiful house, refusing to believe it could be possible.
She pushed open the heavy wooden door and removed her shoes at the entrance.
Wanting to feel the barefoot sensation she loved so much, and in a moment, she was already embraced in Yosef's arms, how happy he was for her and proud of the uniform she wore.

Once she was free from his embrace, she lifted her head and was surprised to see the dining room still organized, the wooden tables with matching chairs in their places, the bar with tall wooden stools in front of it, and all the bottles of drink on the shelves, mostly.
Yosef's painting still adorned the surrounding walls.
She was sure she would find everything already packed.
At the edge of the bar, she suddenly noticed a large, charming teddy bear sitting there, almost looking at her.
Its paws were brown, and its glass eyes gleamed at her.
A big smile spread across her face.
She looked at Yosef.
What's this?
Where did that sweet teddy come from?
She asked.
Yosef smiled at her.
Rolf left it for you, wanted you to have something to hug even after he leaves.
She felt a bit like a child excited by a toy, especially moved by the thought behind it.
She approached and hugged her teddy bear, thinking in her heart that she should give it a name, and meanwhile placed it on the armchair to make it feel comfortable.
She passed by Lucy's portrait, looking deep into her late mother's eyes as if asking for strength and as always felt that they returned her gaze.
Joseph's talent made Lucy's eyes look deep into the viewer's soul from her portrait.
Soon I'll water the garden, dear mother, don't worry.
Even if they were leaving, the garden had to be beautiful and blooming.
In her heart she spoke to her.

All Lucy's pride was in that vast garden, with the large neem tree at its center, alongside the fig tree, which remained there from the days when the whole place was just a big sand dune on the way to the sea, and the entrance path adorned with silver baskets and pansies, all coming together to form this expansive enchanted garden.
more than two years had passed since she was no longer there, but her spirit still resided in everything.

Her mother left her in her mind, and mostly in her heart, a guidebook written from years of observation, as if she understood that he couldn't always be relied upon, leaving her often to be the responsible adult before she even turned 16.
She didn't remember another home.

She was two years old and a bit when they arrived, after her parents chose this corner, adjoining the path leading to the sea, connecting four semi-detached houses and turning them into the first hotel in Ashkelon.
Yosif, with his artist soul, couldn't bear the endless white of the sand dune and the whiteness of the surrounding houses.
so he painted the walls pink and the shutters red for two days.
And once his work was done, he placed a sign at the entrance that read in round nice letters, the pink house.

They both in their uniqueness turned this place into a pilgrimage site for all the nations and Bohemia's greats, made it a bustling and meaningful house, a vibrant pink aisle of culture amid a neighborhood of white houses.
Only in this house did she know how to manage even by herself.

She knew that at the end of mopping the floor, she could pour all the remaining water in the bucket along the path behind the kitchen, spread a dry floor cloth, wipe her bare feet on it and walk back inside.
What do people living in other houses do with this water?
Where do they pour it?
And there's the soft armchair in the foyer right next to the piano where she escapes in sad moments, devouring the books she loves so much.
When that's not enough, she pours herself out on the piano in the corner.
which welcomes her with great love even though she plays it only by ear.
Where will the piano go from here?
Who will keep it for her?
What will she do without a piano and an armchair to curl up in?

She went out to the garden and turned on the sprinklers for Lucy, just to make sure she was watching from above, to know she was good at all the tasks left for her, trying to postpone the end, but understanding there was no choice.
Slowly, barefoot, she walked to her little room.
Removing her uniform and changing into her grandpa's jeans and tank top, she sat on the floor and started gathering her few belongings into two small cardboard boxes.
Some rare records, some of her favorite books, three pairs of shoes, a few clothes, a photo album from her childhood, and a few empty bottles of Madame Roche's, her mother's perfume.
wanting to remember her scent.
Thus, in two small cardboard boxes, she packed her life at six in the morning on Sunday.
Wrapped in a uniform, she had shortened and tightened on her own with an unskilled hand.
She gathered her long braid in a pin atop her head, and now she was ready to set out.
She wouldn't let the tears rise within her, but deep inside, her heart was broken.
Yet in his own eyes, the adult, the parent, tears swelled.
He knew what was in her heart, just as in his own.
She gathered herself and walked upright out of the house.
Only at the last moment, the four boarding the bus, she couldn't hold back any longer and turned for one final look back to remember her pink house.
And only then did she step out into the rest of her life.
